modules.description: This module implements the k-medoids clustering algorithm, computing clusters from an array of elements and calculating the total clustering cost. It operates on elements of type `E.t`, using predefined distance metrics and initialization methods. Concrete use cases include partitioning datasets into groups based on similarity, such as clustering geographic locations or categorizing documents by content.

This module performs agglomerative clustering by merging elements based on a metric space structure. It provides functions to create clusters from element lists, truncate clusters at specified depths, and retrieve all clusters with their depths. It works with sets of elements equipped with a distance metric, organizing them into hierarchical cluster trees.

Implements k-means clustering with customizable initialization and termination criteria. Operates on arrays of elements with a defined distance metric, grouping them into clusters based on proximity. Useful for partitioning datasets into distinct groups where cluster centers are iteratively refined.

Implements k-medoids clustering with initialization methods like Forgy and KmedoidsPP, and algorithms such as PAM and VoronoiIteration. Works on arrays of elements with a defined distance metric, producing clustered groups and computing clustering cost. Useful for grouping geographic data points or organizing documents by similarity.

Implements k-means clustering with customizable initialization (Forgy, RandomPartition, KmeansPP) and termination (iteration limit, threshold, constraint combinations). Operates on arrays of elements with a defined distance metric, grouping them into clusters based on proximity. Useful for partitioning datasets into distinct groups where cluster centers are iteratively refined.

Defines distance metrics for clustering algorithms, including operations like computing pairwise distances between data points. Works with numerical data types, particularly integers and floats, organized as individual points or vectors. Used to implement custom distance functions such as Euclidean or Manhattan distance in clustering workflows.

Performs multiple independent runs of a given function, tracking the result with the lowest associated cost. Works with any function that returns a float cost and a value of arbitrary type. Useful for optimization scenarios like running stochastic algorithms several times to pick the best outcome.

This module provides functions for list and array manipulation specific to clustering algorithms. It includes operations for splitting lists, sampling without replacement, initializing cluster centers using the Forgy method, and summing float arrays. These functions are used in implementing clustering routines like k-means.

This module implements agglomerative clustering over elements with a defined distance metric, providing functions to build hierarchical clusters, merge closest clusters iteratively, and extract clusters at specific depths. It operates on sets of elements structured as a metric space, organizing them into a tree of nested clusters. Concrete use cases include grouping numerical data points by Euclidean distance or clustering strings using edit distance.

This module implements clustering algorithms including agglomerative, k-means, and k-medoids, with support for custom distance metrics and initialization strategies. It operates on numerical data points, arrays, and elements with defined metric spaces, organizing them into hierarchical or flat cluster structures. Concrete use cases include grouping geographic coordinates, clustering text by similarity, and partitioning datasets using k-means++ initialization or multi-start optimization.
